solution_line_template: She burnt {burnt_dozens} dozen, cooked {first_cooked_dozens} dozen and then another {second_cooked_dozens} dozen that evening. So she made {burnt_dozens}+{first_cooked_dozens}+{second_cooked_dozens} =<<{burnt_dozens}+{first_cooked_dozens}+{second_cooked_dozens}={total_dozens_made}>>{total_dozens_made} dozen cupcakes
Each dozen makes {cupcakes_per_dozen} cupcakes, so she made {total_dozens_made}*{cupcakes_per_dozen}= <<{total_dozens_made}*{cupcakes_per_dozen}={total_cupcakes_made}>>{total_cupcakes_made} cupcakes
She threw away {dozens_burnt} dozen cupcakes, so {dozens_burnt}*{cupcakes_per_dozen} = <<{dozens_burnt}*{cupcakes_per_dozen}={cupcakes_thrown_away}>>{cupcakes_thrown_away} cupcakes

She made {total_cupcakes_made}, threw away {cupcakes_thrown_away}, ate {first_eaten_cupcakes} and then ate another {second_eaten_cupcakes} so she had {total_cupcakes_made}-{cupcakes_thrown_away}-{first_eaten_cupcakes}-{second_eaten_cupcakes} = <<{total_cupcakes_made}-{cupcakes_thrown_away}-{first_eaten_cupcakes}-{second_eaten_cupcakes}={cupcakes_remaining}>>{cupcakes_remaining} cupcakes left

She sells the {cupcakes_remaining} cupcakes at ${selling_price_per_cupcake} each so she earned {cupcakes_remaining}*{selling_price_per_cupcake} = $<<{cupcakes_remaining}*{selling_price_per_cupcake}={total_earned}>>{total_earned}

She made {total_cupcakes_made} cupcakes at a cost of ${cost_per_cupcake} each for a total cost of {total_cupcakes_made}*${cost_per_cupcake} = $<<{total_cupcakes_made}*{cost_per_cupcake}={total_cost_of_making}>>{total_cost_of_making}

If she made ${total_earned} on the remaining cupcakes and it cost her ${total_cost_of_making} to make all of the cupcakes then her profit is ${total_earned}-${total_cost_of_making} = $<<{total_earned}-{total_cost_of_making}={net_profit}>>{net_profit}
